Post Description:

Post Description:
In the recent two weeks, new cases and clusters have emerged. They are likely the result of increased activities over the year-end period (typically new cases present themselves with a 1-2 week lag). Our vulnerabilities have gone up, and we cannot afford to take any chances. The situation can escalate rapidly especially with Chinese New Year coming up soon. Remember cases spiked after CNY last year, and we had many clusters then linked to CNY activities and gatherings.

So we are making a pre-emptive move now to tighten our measures. Under the current rule, home visits are allowed for up to 8 visitors at any time. From 26 Jan onwards, we will limit such visits to 8 distinct visitors per household per day.  For those who are planning to go out visiting, we strongly advise that you minimise your physical gatherings. In particular over the CNY period, visit your family members only, and do not exceed more than two visits per day. 

When dining out, keep your masks on if you are not eating/drinking, and refrain from singing or talking loudly. So during the lohei, masks must remain on, and there should be no shouting of auspicious phrases. For reunion dinners, keep to one table of not more than 8 pax and ensure there are no multiple table bookings, or intermingling across tables. 

I know many will be disappointed at these new restrictions especially over the festive season. But I hope everyone understands why they are necessary. The virus is raging everywhere in the world. Many places in Asia that have successfully controlled the infection are now seeing a rise in cases. Places like China, Taiwan and Hong Kong have all imposed curbs on their CNY celebrations. 

Likewise, we must be mentally prepared that CNY this year will not be the same as before. It will be quieter and more subdued. We will need to stay disciplined and vigilant. I seek everyone’s cooperation on these new measures. If we all do our part, we can continue to keep the infection under control until we get the vaccines out to everyone in Singapore later this year.
Comments: Mr Wong, I am not disappointed.  We must do our part.  Thank you!

Post Description:
Entering Waterway Primary this morning, I saw our P1 students walking in hand in hand to school with their parents. Many of them were nervous and excited when I met them in the canteen, where they were to bid goodbye to their parents and head to their classrooms. 

But surprisingly, despite first-day jitters, I didn't see any tears. Instead, there were lots of smiles and encouraging words. Teachers were on hand to reassure the P1s and provide close attention to those who needed it. The Principal Mrs Wee told me that with the other levels staying home today, the extra pairs of hands really made a difference in helping to smoothen this transition, and to help the P1s get used to the Safe Management Measures in schools. 

Stay tuned for a video later to hear what some students and parents have to say about their #firstdayofschool!

Post Description:
While we must continue to be vigilant during this period, we also recognise the need for key life events to continue. The Taskforce is therefore easing some restrictions in a calibrated manner.

Marriage solemnisations will be allowed to take place with 50 persons (up from the current 20 persons) at venues such as places of worship, HDB common areas, and other external venues. In addition we will launch a pilot where each wedding couple will be allowed to hold a reception (including food and drinks) with up to 50 attendees in venues that are permitted to serve food and drinks, ie restaurants and hotels. Prevailing safe management measures must be strictly adhered to, eg 5 to a table, wearing of masks, no live performances or singing etc. 

For wakes, we will allow 30 persons (up from 20) to be present at any one time to pay their last respects. 

The above changes will take effect from 4 Aug. The Taskforce will continue to monitor the situation closely, and will consider what other activities can be resumed gradually and safely. But we must all do our part too, by adjusting our expectations, lifestyles and norms, as we are not going back to the way things were before Covid-19.
Comments: Thank you Mr Wong for sharing this good news! Really appreciate the hard work and effort from you and your team 😄 on a side note, it would be great if you can credit the photographer who took this picture, i think he/she will be very grateful to you for doing so 😊

I understand many would like to catch up with their friends. But I urge everyone to cooperate and comply with the prevailing rules - go out on your own, or only with members of your households. Exiting the circuit breaker is not a signal that we can now let our guard down. We must stay very disciplined and take responsibility for our actions. Let us all continue to do our part to keep everyone safe from Covid-19.

Photo by NParks

Post Description: Taking safe distancing seriously. We are now doing virtual press conferences for our Covid-19 updates to further minimise contact and keep everyone safe
Comments: In my community of homemakers, we have understood and accepted safe distancing measures while in public spaces. But it has not been clear that the message now is that because of evidence of community spread, we are not to gather even in groups of less than ten for casual or recreational purposes. For instance, some think it is acceptable to go with a few friends to window shop to break the monotony of life, or to meet at a restaurant as long as there are not more than ten people, because the message that we should only go to malls on essential errands etc etc and its rationale are not loudly and clearly communicated to the public. People very much desire to cooperate at such a difficult time as this but because new implementations and advisories are ever so fast changing, I feel it is important to state loud and clear in plain terms and esp the rationale behind each stricter level of advisory. Everyone I know wish to help and cooperate fully in this crisis but sometimes we unwittingly don’t, simply because we have not understood.
